Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 54164-002  
Transaction Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
March 2021 
 
 
 
Enabling the Ecosystem to Improve Access to Green 
Affordable Housing for Women 
(India) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

(as of 2 March 2021)

Page 
TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AT A GLANCE 
I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT  1 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  1 
A.  Justification  1 
B.  Outputs and Activities  4 
C.  Cost and Financing  4

I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) of $1,000,000 from the Urban Climate Change 
Resilience Trust Fund (UCCRTF) will help support the green building ecosystem in the affordable 
housing sector in India. The TA will be executed by ADB, as implemented in coordination with 
IIFL Home Finance Limited (IIFLHF), an affordable housing finance company (HFC) which has 
taken a leadership role in advancing the green affordable housing1 ecosystem in India. Despite 
the fact that residential properties comprise more than 90% of India’s building footprint, few are 
green certified and/or climate resilient.2 The proposed TA will help overcome some of the key 
identified obstacles to building the ecosystem for green certified resilient and affordable housing 
in India, including (i) lack of homebuyer awareness which focuses on the higher construction cost 
rather than the long-term operational cost savings of green buildings, and (ii) lack of housing 
developer experience and knowledge to develop green and climate resilient buildings. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  Need for green housing: Changing climate patterns and global warming coupled with 
increasing urban populations, rising pollution,  deteriorated air quality,  water shortages and 
depleting natural resources have compelled some governments and other stakeholders to take 
steps to address these issues in their urban planning. Construction of green certified residential 
buildings and office spaces is one such critical area which can make a significant positive impact 
on the environment. The 2019 Global Status Report for Buildings and Construction3 shows that 
CO2 emissions from the world’s buildings and their construction remain stubbornly at about 39% 
of total carbon dioxide emissions.  Infrastructure and activities, such as transportation associated 
with construction of buildings, add to the emissions. Further reports4 estimate that the building 
sector consumes approximately 25% of water, 35-40% of energy, and emits 40% of global waste. 
 
Conversely,  important  climate  adaptation  benefits  can  result  from  an  increase  of  green 
construction in the affordable housing segment.  The design methods associated with certified 
green  buildings  result  in  less  emissions,  reduced  landfill  waste,  promotion  of  alternative 
transportation linkages, and increased vegetated land areas to absorb CO2. The promotion of 
green building standards can also help ensure optimal use of natural resources, and reduction of 
waste and pollution, thus contributing to national goals set under the Paris Climate Agreements. 
In addition to climate benefits, green buildings also offer financial benefits to buyers such as 
energy and water savings, lower operating and maintenance costs, and reduced health costs due 
to lower pollution and emissions. 
 
3.  Climate Adaptation in India: India is the fifth most vulnerable country to climate change,5 
with the rank worsening from the 14th spot in 2017. Most parts of India are expected to be 
 
1  Affordable housing is defined by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) covering segments ranging from “Economically 
Weaker Section” (EWS) with family income up to 0.3 million INR per annum, “Low Income Group” (LIG), with income 
between 0.3 million-0.6 million INR, and the “Middle Income Group” (MIG), with income up to 1.8 million INR per 
annum. Reserve Bank of India. RBI Bulletin. 
2  As per ANAROCK group, only 5% of buildings in India are green certified. According to International Finance 
Corporation’s (IFC) Green Buildings Market Intelligence, only 2% of green buildings in India are residential. IFC. 
2018. Green Buildings Market Intelligence. India Country Profile. Washington D.C. 
3  United Nations Environment Program. 2019. Global Status Report for Buildings and Construction: Towards a zero-
emission, efficient and resilient buildings and construction sector.  
4  ANAROCK Group. 2018. Go Green The Mantra for Sustainable Living. Mumbai.  
5  D. Eckstein, et al. 2020. Global Climate Risk Index 2020. Berlin.

2   
impacted by more extreme temperatures, more intense precipitation and flooding, more damaging 
cyclones, and greater variability in water availability.6 Developments in coastal regions will also 
be vulnerable to sea level rise, more severe storm surges and erosion, while those in mountain 
regions could experience more landscape instability, along with changing patterns and volumes 
of meltwater. Low-income populations in India are particularly vulnerable given the high exposure 
of their livelihoods and homes to climate hazards, yet limited resources to protect against climate 
shocks. All of these factors contribute to the urgent need for low-regret7 adaptations to climate 
change that will deliver benefits to vulnerable groups in the face of rising climate risks.  
 
4.  Housing in India: There is a shortage of housing units in India, estimated at 18.78 million 
in urban areas and 43.7 million9 in rural areas. The Ministry of Housing and Urban Poverty 
Alleviation estimated more than 90% of the housing deficit to be in the affordable housing 
segment, primarily for the Economically Weaker Section (EWS) and Low Income Group (LIG)10, 
leaving a substantial gap between demand and supply. At the same time, the ecosystem for green 
affordable housing is nascent, and the climate risk impact of meeting this vast housing deficit in 
the EWS and LIG segments can be substantial if adequate attention is not given to construction 
in a climate sustainable way. Given the significant demand for affordable housing, and the fact 
that more than 70% of the buildings needed by 2030 are yet to be constructed to meet the deficit, 
some state governments are beginning to provide tax incentives for developers to incorporate 
green features in their construction.11 
 
5.  Despite  low  baselines  in  terms  of  consumer  adoption  of  green  construction  in  the 
residential sector, India is one of the leading countries in terms of its initiatives on commercial 
green buildings and ranks only second to the USA in terms of the number of green technology 
projects  and  built-up  area.12 As  of  September  2017,  more  than  4,300  projects  covering 
approximately 4.7 billion square feet have registered for green technology. This constitutes 
around 5% of the total buildings in India; however, this is estimated to more than double and reach 
around 10 million square feet by 2022, with a value of $35- $50 billion.   
 
6.  One of the main challenges towards adoption of green housing is lack of awareness 
among home buyers.13 Most buyers simply perceive that green buildings are expensive and are 
financially not feasible as they focus on the higher construction cost (up to +12%) and are not 
aware of the long-term operational cost savings (up to -35%). Secondly, housing developers lack 
the experience and knowledge to develop green buildings. Thirdly, higher costs of equipment and 
products used in green construction deter developers, particularly the smaller ones and in the 
affordable segment. Lack of adequate incentives and additional compliance associated with green 
certification also deter developers. Finally, there is a dearth of adequately trained green building 
professionals such as architects, engineers, contractors, policy makers and workers who possess 
the skills required for green construction, particularly in the affordable housing segment. There is 
therefore a strong need to address the significant knowledge gap and incentive structure that 
 
6  Climate Links, USAID. 2017. Climate Risk Profile: India.  
7  Given the opportunity cost associated with any adaptation in construction methods the term ‘low’ as opposed to ‘no’ 
regret is preferred. R.L. Wilby and S.  Dessai. 2010. Robust adaptation to climate change. Weather. pp. 65, 180-185.  
8  M. Jena. 2016. U.N. expert calls for India to ramp up action to help slum dwellers. Reuters. 
9  S. Singh, M. Swaminathan, and V.K. Ramachandran. 2013. Housing Shortages in Rural India. The Journal of the 
Foundation for Agrarian Studies. July. 
10 See definition on income ranges for EWS and LIG in Footnote 1. 
11 International Finance Corporation. Green Buildings Market Intelligence India Country Profile Washington DC. 
12 United Nations Environment Program. 2019. Global Status Report for Buildings and Construction: Towards a zero-
emission, efficient and resilient buildings and construction sector 
13 World Green Building Trends. 2018. Dodge Data and Analytics, Bedford, MA.

3 
exists on the part of home buyers, developers, regulators, and the entire affordable housing 
ecosystem.  
 
7.  Within the already challenging market for green buildings, women have been under-
represented in infrastructure planning processes and have had little control over city resources or 
to make them work to their advantage. Housing design with facilities for water and toilets, and 
with better linkages to markets, schools, childcare, health and transport services, can all increase 
women’s abilities to be more productive and participative.14 Gender-responsive urban planning 
can contribute to gender equality and women’s empowerment in significant ways through the 
provision of (i) accessible and affordable infrastructure and services for water supply and 
sanitation, waste disposal, electricity, transport, and housing; (ii) clean environment and better 
health;  and  (iii)  safety  and  security.15 This  TA  will  incorporate  best  practices  on  gender 
mainstreaming in green housing and develop appropriate guidelines for the industry, as a 
measure to seek to address structural biases against women. 
 
8.  As a partner for TA implementation, IIFLHF has created cross sector initiatives such as 
“Kutumb”16, a dialogue platform to bring together industry experts, housing developers and other 
key stakeholders to generate a larger scale and more sustainable commitment to the expanded 
supply of green housing, through increased awareness building, policy dialogue and technical 
capacity building for actors contributing to the supply of green housing stock in India. The larger 
objective  of  the  TA  is  to  drive  increased  adoption  of  green  and  climate  resilient  building 
technologies by developers and align them to the needs of the home buyer in the affordable 
segment. The company has conducted six Kutumb events so far, each event educating an 
average of 100 developers on the benefits of green certified housing construction. IIFLHF has 
also established a 'Green Value Partner' (GVP) program wherein it partners with developers to 
provide specific technical expertise throughout the project lifecycle and certification process, 
through its dedicated team of technical experts, certified by one of the green certification agencies 
such as GRIHA or IGBC.17 IIFLHF seeks to further enhance its capacity to bridge existing 
knowledge gaps regarding green construction methods for affordable housing and to improve the 
supply of and demand for green affordable housing through the range of proposed TA activities.  
 
9.  The largest share of the TA funding will be dedicated to ecosystem building activities that 
benefit the Indian housing finance industry at large. These include activities such as certification 
of housing developers in 'green' building standards (IGBC and GRIHA), capacity building support 
for local and state housing boards to develop an incentive structure for green affordable housing, 
knowledge events to convene and build awareness with key stakeholders core to scaling the 
supply of and demand for green affordable housing, as well as providing incentives for firms to 
innovate in the development of new climate risk mitigation and adaptation technologies for green 
building methods.  Additional outputs include collaboration with national/ international centers of 
excellence to develop a publication on technology innovations in climate resilient housing, and on 
green  affordable  housing  certification  standards  to  build  awareness.  These  activities  are 
supported with counterparty resources from IIFLHF and are expected to become a systemic part 
of IIFLHF’s strategy with its own funding past the implementation period of the TA.  
   
 
14 UNDP India. 2009. Addressing Gender Concerns in India’s Urban Renewal Mission. New Delhi.  
15 Asian Development Bank, 2013. Gender-Inclusive Approaches in Urban Development. Manila. 
16 IIFL Home Loan.  
17 The detailed criteria for green certification by each of the agencies can be found at the links below: Green Rating for 
Integrated Habitat Assessment and Indian Green Building Council Green Factory Buildings.

4   
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
10.  With the support of the TA resources and ADB’s knowledge inputs from expertise in urban 
development  and  affordable  housing,  IIFLHF  aims  to  play  a  leadership  role  in  catalyzing 
increased awareness and appropriate regulatory incentives on the part of policy makers at the 
local, state, and national levels, as well as build technical capabilities on the part of housing 
developers across various regions of India regarding the benefits of implementing certified green 
housing. Through the proposed TA administered by ADB, IIFLHF will also benefit from expertise, 
best practices and lessons learned from other UCCRTF supported projects, which can be 
reflected in the ongoing review of and inputs into TA activities conducted through the execution 
period. The TA seeks to achieve the following results by December 2022: 
 
(i)  Capacity building and trainings: IIFLHF will organize training sessions for its technical 
team’s  on  site  risk  assessment  and  climate  adaptation  measures,  and  on  the  green 
certification process for climate resilient buildings and arrange for individual certifications from 
IGBC/GRIHA for its technical staff. Similar training will also be provided for developers’ staff. 
In addition, IIFLHF will facilitate trainings for various local or state housing boards on the site 
risk assessment, climate adaptation measures, and the green certification process. 
 
(ii) Knowledge  exchange  events:  IIFLHF  will  organize  Kutumb  meetings  to  facilitate  the 
exchange of ideas and increase awareness among various stakeholders regarding the climate 
risk mitigation and climate risk adaptation benefits and appropriate policy frameworks to 
promote adoption of green certified housing standards in the affordable housing segment. The 
company will conduct at least one National Level  thought leadership event on Climate 
Resilient and Green Affordable Housing each year during the TA’s life and will also conduct 
at least thought leadership and knowledge product to disseminate lessons learned and best 
practices in green affordable housing with HFCs and other affordable housing stakeholders 
in South Asia. To promote the uptake of climate resilient green certified housing, IIFLHF will 
conduct  community  engagement  activities  with potential  borrowers  from EWS  and LIG 
segments, and female borrowers.  
 
(iii) Market research activities and Innovative Technologies: The TA activities will include 
several market research initiatives across the entire value chain of climate resilient green 
housing and formulate strategies to build the ecosystem. These will include: (i) assessing 
current awareness regarding climate resilient green affordable housing by prospective buyers 
and developers and establishing a baseline of consumer understanding; (ii) formulating a 
unified green building ratings system to encompass tailored adaptations to the local climate 
zones of various regions across India; (iii) establishing a system to integrate green lending 
and climate adaptation strategies in the context of affordable housing; (iv) identifying cost 
effective innovative green technologies by collaborating with suitable research institutes; and 
(v) preparing guidelines for mainstreaming gender in green housing. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,150,000, of which $1,000,000 will financed on a grant basis 
by  Urban Climate  Change Resilience Trust  Fund  (UCCRTF)18 under  the Urban  Financing 
Partnership Facility (UFPF) and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in 
 
18 Financing partners: the Rockefeller Foundation and the governments of Switzerland and the United Kingdom.

5 
Appendix 1. Specific funding limitations that is set by ADB will be incorporated in the TA 
Agreement.  
 
12.  IIFLHF  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  staff  resources,  office 
accommodation, supplies and administrative assistance, and other in-kind contributions. IIFLHF 
will also finance and administer $150,000 from its own resources, separate from ADB’s fund flow, 
as counterparty contribution towards the TA activities during the implementation period. IIFL was 
informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA and its Private Sector Operations Department, Financial 
Institutions Division (PSFI) will be the focal point. ADB will be responsible for all technical 
implementation issues. Consultants will remit deliverables to ADB.  ADB will disburse the TA 
funds directly to the consultants based on their respective consulting contracts, following ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time  to time). TA 
implementation is expected to begin in April 2021 and be completed by 31 December 2022. 
IIFLHF will continue to implement all the TA activities beyond December 2022 using its own funds. 
 
14.  The execution of the TA requires the selection of consultants for which ADB will conduct 
procurement and ensure use of funds in compliance with relevant ADB policies, as well as monitor 
outputs and achievement of development effectiveness indicators.  IIFLHF will be responsible for 
the preparation of the progress monitoring and evaluation (M&E) reports during the project and 
provide ADB with annual TA progress reports, including information on the execution of target 
results. 
 
15.  Pursuant  to  Article  14(iii)  of  the  ADB  Charter19,the  applicable  developing  member 
country's government's no objection to the implementation of the TA in the relevant country will 
be established before the implementation or financing of the TA in that country. 
 
16.  A  summary  of  implementation  arrangements  is  accessible  from  the  list  of  linked 
documents in Appendix 2. Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and the Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as 
amended from time to time). The TA will engage the services of three national consulting firms, 
one for each of the outputs, and detailed qualification criteria have been outlined in each case.  
 
17.  ADB has prepared detailed TOR and budget estimates for consultants, in consultation 
with IIFHL. The expertise and the key selection and evaluation criteria will be set out in the TOR 
or requests for proposal (RFPs) for each contract.  
 
18.  Cofinancier requirements. For UCCRTF, PSFI will submit annual progress reports on 
activities, disbursements and the inception, interim, final and completion reports of the project. 
PSFI  will  also  facilitate  the  trust  fund’s  secretariat  to  join  grant  review  missions  or 
events/workshops organized by the project, as required.  
 
19.  Integrity due diligence has been conducted in accordance with ADB’s Integrity Due 
Diligence Guidelines for Non-sovereign Operations. Based on the information provided, and in 
the absence of any other reported matter that could raise an integrity-related issue, the potential 
 
19 ADB 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.

6   
integrity and reputational risks arising from ADB’s association with IIFLHF is assessed as “Low to 
Medium”. 
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis in 
association with IIFL Home Finance Limited for Enabling the Ecosystem to Improve Access to 
Green Affordable Housing for Women in India, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
                                                                                         Masatsugu Asakawa 
President 
19 March 2021
